text:
Morning!  I guess I'm coming to the betfair game a little late but better late than never :slightly_smiling_face:  I'm having trouble keeping up with markets using the delayed key though and have a slightly noob question.
I've seen it suggested that I can get my key for the live feed activated as long as I'll be placing a "reasonable" number of bets?  What sort of magnitude is considered "reasonable"?  Until I have more experience, I don't want to be risking huge sums and I have no innate sense of what people consider to be large or small bets and volumes?
Many thanks!  - Jon

elements.text: Morning!  I guess I'm coming to the betfair game a little late but better late than never

I'm having trouble keeping up with markets using the delayed key though and have a slightly noob question.

Until I have more experience, I don't want to be risking huge sums and I have no innate sense of what people consider to be large or small bets and volumes?
Many thanks!  - Jon

text: Yes, the delayed key is useless. <@U4H19D1D2> can get your live key activated for free but there is the expectation that you will be placing bets and not just collecting data. I'm not sure anyone can give you a concrete rule for how much volume you should be doing

elements.text: Yes, the delayed key is useless.

can get your live key activated for free but there is the expectation that you will be placing bets and not just collecting data. I'm not sure anyone can give you a concrete rule for how much volume you should be doing

text: Thanks Mo - I guess I'd expected that there wasn't a fixed boundary for this but was wondering if it would be problematic if I was to be making minimum-sized bets until I'd got a better feel for how everything moves or if the volume of bets I made was relatively small whilst I'm developing and testing.

elements.text: Thanks Mo - I guess I'd expected that there wasn't a fixed boundary for this but was wondering if it would be problematic if I was to be making minimum-sized bets until I'd got a better feel for how everything moves or if the volume of bets I made was relatively small whilst I'm developing and testing.

text: All we can definitely say is that zero bets would be problematic

elements.text: All we can definitely say is that zero bets would be problematic

text: Obviously you cannot force betting opportunities to materialise but subscribing to many more markets than you are actually betting on is probably also not a good idea

elements.text: Obviously you cannot force betting opportunities to materialise but subscribing to many more markets than you are actually betting on is probably also not a good idea

text: Sure, makes sense.  I guess all I can do is suck-it-and-see and try not to abuse the system whilst I'm getting going!  At least there's some historic data for some markets so I can start with those and hopefully avoid having to subscribe to too much.

elements.text: Sure, makes sense.  I guess all I can do is suck-it-and-see and try not to abuse the system whilst I'm getting going!  At least there's some historic data for some markets so I can start with those and hopefully avoid having to subscribe to too much.

text: hey, i’ve started using flumine a few days ago. is it possible to unsubscribe from an event_id within my strategy? for example, if the match gets passed the 65' mark i would like to stop the stream for that particular event

elements.text: hey, i’ve started using flumine a few days ago. is it possible to unsubscribe from an event_id within my strategy? for example, if the match gets passed the 65' mark i would like to stop the stream for that particular event

text: <@U019Z6V6DHS> can you not just have logic within check_market_book function to return False if your strategy doesnt want to process the market_book

elements.text: can you not just have logic within check_market_book function to return False if your strategy doesnt want to process the market_book

text: I think unsubbing will not be worth it if you run multiple strategies on one instance, for example one strategy might only need the first 65 mins the second strategy the last 25-30 mins. You start to cap yourself unnecessarily, making things messy down the line when you add more and more strategies.

elements.text: I think unsubbing will not be worth it if you run multiple strategies on one instance, for example one strategy might only need the first 65 mins the second strategy the last 25-30 mins. You start to cap yourself unnecessarily, making things messy down the line when you add more and more strategies.

text: :point_up: also you want to record your profit and winners/losers come closure

elements.text: also you want to record your profit and winners/losers come closure

text: <@U01NJ85MP7F> basic / advanced historical data is pretty much useless and pro data is costly. I d rather subscribe to a market and put the money in bets instead of buying the pro-data with it. Having a strategy running will probs give you a better feel for the market and even if your "strategy" sucks, as long as your placing bets on a runner with low price spread, you wont lose a lot. Even if you place low stake bets at random, you ll win some and lose some and it would take some time until you actually reach what you would ve paid for the pro data set

elements.text: basic / advanced historical data is pretty much useless and pro data is costly. I d rather subscribe to a market and put the money in bets instead of buying the pro-data with it. Having a strategy running will probs give you a better feel for the market and even if your "strategy" sucks, as long as your placing bets on a runner with low price spread, you wont lose a lot. Even if you place low stake bets at random, you ll win some and lose some and it would take some time until you actually reach what you would ve paid for the pro data set

text: I guess buying pro-data is the faster way of gaining data then recording it yourself, so if you think waiting for your own recorded data would hold you back, buying may be the better move

elements.text: I guess buying pro-data is the faster way of gaining data then recording it yourself, so if you think waiting for your own recorded data would hold you back, buying may be the better move

text: I wasn't expecting them to be great - but if you get enough crappy forecasts you can use wisdom of the crowds to make a better one.

elements.text: I wasn't expecting them to be great - but if you get enough crappy forecasts you can use wisdom of the crowds to make a better one.

text: For example if you have a super-good forecasting system but it decided that two horses had identical scores then you may as well employ a not so good forecast as a tie breaker... it would be better than random choice.

elements.text: For example if you have a super-good forecasting system but it decided that two horses had identical scores then you may as well employ a not so good forecast as a tie breaker... it would be better than random choice.

text: not sure I agree on this, you have a 'super-good' model which ideally tells you where the value is, why when it doesn't detect value would you find a random forecast and use it? Seems very random to me

elements.text: not sure I agree on this, you have a 'super-good' model which ideally tells you where the value is, why when it doesn't detect value would you find a random forecast and use it? Seems very random to me

text: In general if you have multiple imperfect forecasters of something then employing a weighted sum of their estimates will yield greater accuracy than simply choosing the best of them. You can tune the weights from historical data.

elements.text: In general if you have multiple imperfect forecasters of something then employing a weighted sum of their estimates will yield greater accuracy than simply choosing the best of them. You can tune the weights from historical data.
